info.type: Character from Star Trek: the Next Generation she most resembles

figure.figcaption: Cally gets her boots on the ground during Bounty

content.p: We first meet Cally during Time Squad. She's a guerrilla fighter on the planet of Saurian Major, with a really cool steam-punk gun. She's the last surviving member of her cell and had originally planned to die fighting the Federation.

Cally suffers from telepathy and comes from the planet Auron, like Saymon from The Web and LehanMentioned in name only from Bounty. Auron seems a strangely honourable place - Cally feels unable to return, until she has carried out her mission, which appears to be to destroy the Federation single-handed. They must have really wanted rid of her.

I get the feeling that Cally was originally intended to be a more hands-on character, to contrast with Vila and Avon's self-preservation. Jenna may have an idealistic side, but it was really only Blake who willingly threw himself into danger, until Cally came along.
Ultimately, she's underused in this capacity and Dayna seemed to slot into this role, in the second series.
Perhaps Cally's telepathic abilities suggested a more sensitive role. Unfortunately, in practise, Cally is often left on the sidelines, with little important to do.

Jan Chappell, who played Cally, felt that she wanted a larger role in the second series. What I find interesting about the world of Blake's 7 is that as a society, women and men seem to have complete equality - women are in positions of power throughout the series and this is not questioned in-universe.
Unfortunately, Jan Chappell (and Sally Knyvette, who played Jenna, who also felt underused) had a point - Blake's female crew members in the first series were often placed in the background.

It's interesting to contrast this with a show such as Game of Thrones, where women's place in society is subject to all kinds of restrictions, and yet women characters share screen time with men and are clearly defined characters in their own right.
